Legal_Issue: Whether the trademark VICTOR HUGO & Design is confusingly similar to HUGO BOSS
Evidence_Assessment: Registrar reviewed evidence; appellant submitted new evidence on appeal
Burden_of_Proof: Appellant failed to prove no likelihood of confusion
Legal_Rule: s. 16(3) of the Trade-marks Act â€“ prohibition on registration due to confusion; s. 6(5) factors for assessing confusion
Procedural_Issue: Application of legal tests and consideration of relevant evidence by the Registrar
Decision_Maker: Registrar of Trademarks, affirmed by Federal Court
Key_Evidence_Considered: Similarity in appearance (shared 'HUGO'), differences in sound, distinctiveness, prior use of HUGO BOSS, lack of use of VICTOR HUGO at filing, overlapping goods and trade channels
Legal_Framework: Canadian trademark law, specifically confusion analysis under Trade-marks Act
Applicant_Challenge: Appellant challenged the opposition to registration
Court_Result: Federal Court upheld the Registrar's decision
Defendant_Response: Respondent opposed registration on grounds of confusion
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, usage history, trademark design comparison
Outcome: Registration refused due to likelihood of confusion
Remedy_Sought: Appeal of Registrar's refusal to register
Resolution_Mechanism: Administrative review followed by judicial appeal
Legal_Provision: s. 16(3), s. 6(5) of the Trade-marks Act
Applicable_Process: Trademark opposition and appeal process under Trade-marks Act
